projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: An ESSAY to Silence the Outcry That has been made in ſome Places againſt Regular Singing. IN A SERMON Preach'd at Framingham,
By the Reverend Mr. Joſiah Dwight, Paſtor of the Church of CHRIST in Woodſtock.
BOSTON: Printed for John Eliot, and Sold at his Shop at the South-End of the Town. 1725.

div.head: The Unreaſonable Outcrys, againſt Regular Singing Silenc'd.

q.p: —Theſe that have turned the World upſide down, are come hither alſo.

div.p:
THEY that firſt ſet up, as the Spreaders of the Goſpel, and to give their teſtimony to Chriſt and his Doctrine, had ſeen little beſide Boats and Men: a few illiterate Fiſhermen with a Publican and Tent maker; a ſtrange undertaking, for ſuch unaccompliſhed Orators, to try to convert the World to Christ, and to ſubject the powerful, learned and wiſe, to the foot of a crucified Perſon! but they forgot not Chriſt's parting Promiſe, Mat. 28.20. Go ye therefore & teach all nations; — and lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world. And failed not to lean on Divine Aids and Aſſiſtance; which brought the matter on to a wonderful Perſection, in a little time; tho' they met with not only cold entertainment: but damping repulſe, and harſh treatment, when they firſt preached Chriſt, to an ignorant, depraved, atheiſtical and infidel World; as the Text intimates; which ſets forth, the bitter charge lay'd upon Paul & Silas, for only Scripture reaſoning concerning Chriſt, and his Reſurrection. The charge lay'd upon them, by the implacable outragious Jews, was, as if they went about only upon a ſeditious Deſign, & as State troublers; when they ſought 〈◊〉 worſe thing, than to perſuade the Theſſalonians,
(where the preaching now was) to turn from dumb idols to ſerve the living God. The Rabble counted it very criminal, for Jaſon their Host to harbour them, and took Bail belike of him for their appearance, when they ſhould be call'd for to Examination.
The Words may be conſider'd as a bitter, cauſeleſs Charge. Where obſerve,
1.The Perſons charged; Paul, & Silas his Colleague, that were out upon no other but the Goſpel deſign.

2.Obſerve the matter of the Charge; viz. that they (and their followers) had turned the world upſide down. A proverbial ſay, but high charge! and their meaning probably was that they ſtirred up the world to Inſurrection and Sedition, a grievous Charge! — But the comfort was, (to ſpeak on the Apoſtles ſide) it was utterly falſe, (like that of Tertullus againſt Paul, Acts 24 5. ſays he, We have found this man a pestilent fellow, & a mover of ſedition, &c. For all the Jews were ſo ready to confirm his lie, v.9 The Jews alſo aſſented, ſaying, that thoſe things were ſo) In a good ſenſe, it were well if the charge in the Text had been true, for the depraved world wanted then, (and never more perhaps) to be turned clean out of their idolatrous, vicious Cuſtoms; and to be brought to the Faith and Purity of the Goſpel. But theſe (the only Tumult and Uproar-makers of that Day;) continue the Charge, v. 7. for that they brought in Customs contrary to Caeſar's. Whereas, theſe Servants of God, try'd to advance the ſpiritual Kingdom of Chriſt, without the leaſt Injury to the Roman Empire: that the Jews knew to be ſo in their Conſciences; but caſt the wicked Aſperſion on them, to make them odious to the people; and pretended regard to Caeſar's Decrees, only to ruin Chriſt's Servants, and hinder the Goſpel: whereas the traduced perſons, honoured the Emperor, pray'd for his Life, for a proſperous Reign, and valiant Armies; a faithful Senate, diſcreet Counſel, a good People, and a quiet World. For this they taught, Tit. 3.1. Put 'em in mind to be ſubject to principalities, & powers, to obey magistrates, to be ready to every good work &c. And
Yet was the world (at that time all gone to naught;) ſet to miſrepute them, and the whole Goſpel deſign, viz. to advance a divine Knowledge and Purity, with Reformation of Life.

3. Obſerve, a farther Aggravation inſiſted on, are come hither alſo. O Neſandous! It was bad eno' to go to other places, and ſpread their leaven, but quite unpardonable to go near the Chargers. Thus they proceed in Accumulation againſt the Servants of God, till out of breath: for men will be as violent in a bad cauſe ſometimes, viz. when miſperſuaded, as others are in a good one. All that I ſhall obſerve to you from the words is this. viz.

div.head: DOCTRINE.

q.hi: That the Goſpel itſelf, when firſt advanced in the World, and the first Preachers of it, had a formidable Outcry raiſed upon them.

div.p:
The Malignant world, did not know how to ſpeak bad eno', and contemptuouſly eno' hereof they tho't. What ſcorn and hard frumps had Paul and his Doctrine from the Athenian Philoſophers? v.18. Some ſaid what will this babbler ſay? other ſome, He ſeemeth to be a ſetter Forth of ſtrange gods, &c. The Apoſtles offered nothing more harſh to Reaſon, than convincing proofs, that Chriſt was the appointed, and expected Meſſiah to come & ſave the world; and irrefragable Confirmations of the truth of his Reſurrection, that mon might be perſuaded, they had a living Saviour to trust in; and that they might quit the vices ſpoken of in Rom. 1.30.1 Cor. 6.10. Tit. 3.3. Gal. 5.21.2 Tim. 3.2. And get waſhed, ſanctified, justified, &c. And appear with the ſpirit of love, joy, peace, long ſuffering, gentleneſs, goodneſs, faithfulneſs, meekneſs, temperance and the like, as a proof that they had cloſed with the Saviour of the world, as their Head and Saviour. And could this hurt any, need it to have diſturbed any! Yet harſh and very unwelcome treatment, had the Goſpel and the firſt Preachers of it, when Chriſt
any more inſtance of this thing, it is but turning back to what the Apostles, at their firſt ſetting into the Miniſtry, met with, Acts 4.18. & 5.40. That was the unpardonable Crime, viz. to preach Chriſt crucified; for fear men ſhould get into a new & better way of Salvation, than that of following their fooliſh ſuperstitions, the Commandments of men, that brought more gain to them, than profit to any body elſe —. Thus Chriſtianity notwithſtanding its brightneſs and purity, was not only expos'd naked in the day of its Birth, but made odious to the People.
Queſt. Whence was it thus?

Anſ. 1. The first Preachers of the Goſpel, were not ſuch promiſing, taking, quaint men. This was the exception againſt Paul, 1 Cor. 2.4. And my ſpeech, & my preaching was not with enticing words of mans wiſdom, but in demonstration of the Spirit, and of power. Which the Apoſtle acknowledged, under the Denomination of infirmity in the fleſh, Gal. 4 13. A crucified Chriſt was the Rhetorick! The Roman Empire was now at its height, Philoſophy & Eloquence in its flower & vigour, and the Sages of that time puſh'd againſt the Diſciples of Chriſt and their Doctrine with their might, as fine undertakers (to ſpeak ironically) to new model the World. (Say they) No, the meſſages of God himſelf ſhall be ſlighted, if brought by ſuch hands: like as the Emulation ſhewed itſelf at the time of the Reformation, under Luther's preaching, when many Church Dignitarys & Eccleſiaſticks could not but own, that ſundry things wanted Reformation in the Church, but could not bear it ſhould be lead on by a ſorry Monk.

2. The Goſpel in its Doctrine & Deſign is very contrary to men's Lusts. And hence might proceed the oppoſition made unto it. This corrupt nature is very fond of, & doth not know how to away with the hard ſayings of the Goſpel about them, to deny themſelves, & take up their croſs, plucking out a right eye, leaving mammon, and laying up treaſure on Earth, giving liberally to the poor, & depending upon Heavenly Refundments, loving
Christ, &c. which makes ſome go away from the hearing with damp, as the young man, who when he heard that ſaying, went away ſorrowful, for he had great poſſeſſions. Mat. 9.22. And others ſet up with bold rages, and try to ſpurn at the Goſpel, and run over it.

3. Meerly for its newneſs the Goſpel might be excepted againſt. For our nature is apt to be fond of things we have had a long Intimacy with, and apt to recoyl at Innovation, if never ſo much for the better. So you ſhall ſee ſome fond of an old houſe, 8 houſe implements, cloaths, hats &c. and if thoſe that are never ſo much better & more uſeful, be offered in their room, they are ſlighted, becauſe thoſe they have had ſuch long acquaintance with, are ſo dear to them. So their old Superſtitions, corrupt Cuſtoms and Idolatries, the infidel world would not part with, for a ſound Goſpel —

USE. Hence the best things that God has ſent us into the World may be miſconstrued & miſrepreſented. When God ſent Chriſt into the World, ſome ſaid he was a friend of Publicans & Sinners, & held a compact with Belzebub, to ſlur & blaſpheme his mighty works. And the Goſpel was by ſome reputed babbling, & a ſetting forth of strange gods. And the Apoſtles, whoſe feet ſhou'd have been beautiful, for bringing the glad & gracious tidings of peace & reconciliation by Christ, they were counted pestilent fellows & mad men. But ſurely this ought not ſo to be. This was one effect of the miſconduct of Reaſon depraved, & benighted with the fall, that in ſome caſes it no better diſcerned good from evil. Whence I would take occaſion, to offer to the Conſciences of ſome Neighbours & Brethren, that appear not ſo well ſatisfied, about the Eſſay of Regulation & Amendment, of the defects of our public Pſalmody, & to have too tort & ſmart Objections, viz. that they may miſs it, & offend against the generation of the juſt, tho' they ſeem to be pretty ſure to themſelves; That I am well perſuaded, 'ere this Generation paſs away, thouſands upon better conſideration, will ſee reaſon to retract precipitant Cenſures, on conſcionable endeavours, to 〈◊〉 the religious Intereſts of New Engliſh Churches, by
to them, lead wrong in an affair of this Nature. But they have ſo learned Christ, and ſo they underſtand the Goſpel, as they have held forth to you, relating to this Subject. And in relation to ſomething further that may be added on this head, I would premiſe,

1. That I can't ſee there ſhould be any holineſs in a Tune; tho' there be holineſs in the matter of a ſacred Song, to which a Tune is required when it is ſung. Singing I take to be but melodious reading, & who can ſhew an Inſtitution for the ſpecial moding a Service; nor ſhould any miſtake from the propinquity of a Tune, to the matter of a ſacred Song, to the mingling and counting that which is unhallowed, with that which is holy—. The grave Tunes uſed in foreign Churches, are no more holy than ours, nor ours, than theirs; for tho' the Bible be an holy Book on all conſiderations, yet the Cover put on only to preſerve, and put honour thereon, none can imagine to be holy. And tho' Chriſt put honour on a certain Tune, (if we knew which of them it was) that he uſed to ſing an Hymn with, at the head of his family, & at the firſt Adminiſtration of the ſecond New Teſtament Sacrament, & laſt public Service he was in on Earth, yet I don't conceive that hereby he put holineſs thereinto. And ſuppoſe it to be as likely that he uſed then one of thoſe Tunes, that are now excepted againſt by ſome, as any other; wherefore I would not have any go too faſt in rejecting, or putting a ſlight upon any particular Tune, that is uſed in the Churches, & approved by the skilful, learned & judicious, leaſt (inverting Luk. 16 15. for a ſeaſonable check here) they be found abominating that which is approv'd in Heaven, & was uſed by Chriſt in his Family on Earth.

2. Singing is partly a natural, & partly an acquired Gift. The To canere, or poſſe canendi, is concreated with us; the Ars canendi is an acquiſition by practice, & God's bleſſing thereon. The poſſe of ſinging is in-lay'd with us by the God of nature, (together with the ſeeing Eye & hearing Ear, Prov. 10.12.) And which Singers riſe to ſome expertneſs in uſing, by the Divine bleſſing, on their reading and hearing the Rules of ſinging, & practiſing thereon, and by minding & conforming to the Voices of them that were
Singers before them. Now ſome have a natural Genius, Sweetneſs, and Governableneſs of the Organs, & Strength of Voice above others: but there are but few indeed, than would fall ſhort, of following a Tune in deſireable manner, if they would but give their minds to it, and try for it. But ſtill

3 It is a good Gift from the Father of Lights if any can Sing well. Jam. 1.17 Every good gift, & every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of Lights, &c. And he that ſet up Solomon to ſhine with wiſdom in Iſrael, made David eminently skilful this way, among his people; in which reſpect, as in many beſide he ſerved his Generation; for the diſpenſation of the Spirit is given to every man to profit withal, be he Prince or Subject: And as every one hath received the Gift, let him be a Civil or Eccleſiaſtical Ruler; ſo let him minifier the ſame, that God in all things might be glorified. By what I can learn from the lively Oracles, David (& no doubt by Heavens direction) was the firſt that introduced ſinging into the Church of God, that aſſiſtant to the devotion of the godly; and I take him to be at the head of the Regulation of the ſacred Muſick, for Harmony & Concord at that glorious Solemnity of removing the Ark to the choſen place for it. 1 Chron. 15.16, 22. And other Feſtivals in Iſrael. As David was ſerviceable to the civil Intereſt of his people, in guarding the Country, & by encouraging trade and buſineſs among his Subjects, for ſuch was his upright and princely behaviour at the Court, & ſuch his martial Valour & cunning in the field of War, that he ſoon grew for midable to his Enemies, & an amiable Allie; & every one ready to court him or crouch to him: So beſides this, was he ſerviceable in penning the Pſalms, ſetting the Tunes, & appointing the Singers, & Inſtruments of Muſick, for helping the devotions of the Godly; that it is remembred of him, together with his laſt things & lies as part of his Epitaph, viz. that he was Amanus Pſalmis intra Iſraelitas; and 'tis reckoned among the honours to which David was raiſed, viz. that he was a Pſalmiſt; by which he was as truly great, as by being the anointed of the God of Jacob, a 〈…〉 There is a mathematical proportion in the aſcent,
elevation, & falling of the Voice, which they that ar • ſtudents in the Science can beſt ſpeak to; & which other would preſently come to the knowledge of by ſtudy. The fundamental rules & grounds of all Muſick are but few, but Mathematically certain, & are for all Ages, Nations & Places: tho' as to the particular Tunes the variation is wonderful. There is no Engliſh Pſalm Tune, but may be ſoon leared by them that have an Inſtructor, & give their minds thereto; only let it be remembred, that God who is the Author of all truth, of Theological, Logical, Phyſical, and Ethical, he is ſo of Mathematical & Muſical Truth; whoſe Name is to be praiſed, for the admirable perfection and excellency he has lay'd into the things of nature & art. And as the Conditor & Framer of all things he has ordered the agreement & diſagreement of things, [inter ſe] ſo that tho' a man & brute agree in animation; yet they differ as to reaſon; & the earth & ſea agree in cold, but differ in reſpect of dryness; which is for the ſtudy & contemplation of Philoſophers: So God has ordered Concord & Diſcord in muſical elevations, for the ſtudents in Muſick, that he might be admired in every thing.

4.Yet ſtrenuous driving after a Regulation of defects in Singing, or after additional Tunes I approve not; eſpecially if ſome ſee it not ſo practicable, & lothly come into it. For I reckon it to be in this matter, as with the Church of old, a ſhifting from Judaiſm to Chriſtianity, & ſome not ſufficiently inſtructed, in that liberty purchaſed by the Death of Chriſt, would have the galling Yoke of Ceremonies longer kept on the neck of Diſciples than was fit. Acts 15.1, 5. And certain men which came down from Judea, taught the Brethren, & ſaid, except ye be circumciſed after the manner of Moſes, ye cannot be ſaved, &c. which hurt the whole Intereſt of Chriſtianity, and undervalued the Death of Chriſt in this point; when yet the reſult of the Council was (tho' they knew it was an error contended for) that there ſhould be a preſent forbearance; that by length of time, they might get light, and conviction of things, that, may be, at preſent they did not ſo well ſee thro'; and to preſerve their peace. Act 19.22, &c. This 〈…〉
the Ceremonies were antiquated, and aboliſhed things, dead and done with, and belonged to the Grave of Chriſt; yet for the ſake of ſome ſcrupulous Conſciences, they would not drag them out of doors before their eyes; but let them lie by for a while, till they might be carried out to a decent Funeral. So tho' we have as much liberty to change our Tunes as our Cloaths, as we may ſee reaſon; and to mend the obvious defects in our Tunes as Cloaths: by how much thro' the long uſe, of imperfectly ſounded Tunes in our Congregations, they have gain'd a veneration from ſome, as if a ſort of ſacredneſs with them, that makes them flinch at the ſeeming innovation & real amendment eſſay'd; there ſhould be gentle progreſs (I count) and forbearance of going the whole circle and latitude of our right and claim, leaſt we bear too hard on our Brethren's Spirits, for whom Chriſt dyed.
But next I would ſay ſomething by way of Anſwer to ſome Queries that ſeem to be obtruded, eſpecially ſome of them on the Singing ſide.
Queſt. Is it equal, that the Elderly, ſhould yield, to be turned out of the old way of Singing, to gratify the Youngerly, who urge on a Regulation the moſt.

Anſ. It is not to yield to man but to God, to fall in with a more advantageous way of performing his Worſhip. In the times that we can look back to, there were no ſuch helps and advantages, to get skill in Singing as now; if ſo I Queſtion not, but our Fathers would have fallen in therewith. And that now God has ſtirred up ſome to improve their 〈◊〉 this way, I ſee not but that elder & younger that would have caſes determined by Reaſon and Religion, ought to improve it, and praiſe God for it. The younger Generations have ordinarily, the cleareſt & ſtrongeſt Voices, and ſo it will be to the end of time; & 'tis no wonder if there be ſomething the moſt heard of them, in ſuch an alteration and reformation as ſeems to be now on foot: who yet muſt be adviſed to be ſoberminded, and to be humble and thankful to the Lord, and full of reſpect to Superiours, and fartheſt from Oſtentation and deſpiſing others, tho' grown to Barzillai's condition & infirmity,
〈…〉
and can I diſcern between good & evil? — Can I hear any more the voice of ſinging men & ſinging women? Wherefore ſhould then thy Servant be yet a burden to my Lord the King? And the elder among us muſt be exhorted to comply and fall in with the well approved & promiſing reformation, leaſt their ſharp contradiction to their ſurprize be interpreted at the Supream Bar, their fighting againſt God.
Queſt. Were our Fathers to blame for Singing God's Praiſes in that way that is now cenſur'd for it's defects.

Anſ. Perſons are accepted of God, if with a good and honeſt heart, they Sing, Pray or Read God's Word as well as they can. But to do theſe brokenly, when they might do them more accurately is a diſreſpect & diſhonour to God, & therefore cenſurable. A Perſon performing a holy Service, with many lameneſſes and defects while he don't know better, may be accepted of God; but when he knows how to come to amendment hereof and refuſes, and ſets himſelf againſt it, he will have tho't to Anſwer to God—. And I ſee not but ſome Congregations, and ſundry in many more, are to be blamed for their ignorance and heedleſsneſs about the Tunes, that may be can't diſtinguiſh one Tune from another when Sung, and ſlide out of one Tune into another, and do not mind it, or Sing the Lines of ſeveral Tunes for one: when a little care & ſtudy indeed would have ſaved the Diſorder. Therefore I would propoſe, there might be many Advantages attending a Practice which I could wiſh all our Congregations were come into, viz to name the Tune together with the Pſalm, and all the Skilful of the Congregation be ſure to fall in with the firſt Note & Syllable; nor is this a bare Propoſal without Experiment: for ſome of us have been ſome time in proof hereof, and ſee its Expediency.
Queſt. This new way is not Singing in the Spirit, is it?

Anſ. As much as the old way is, and no odds in that! But it is not the outward ſounding of a Song any way, that amounts to that; where this is all with any Sinners, they are but as ſounding Braſs, & a tinkling Cymbal, let their Voices be never ſo good and Skill 〈…〉
with the zeal and integrity of the Heart, and by the rules of (Joh. 4.24. God is a Spirit, and they that worſhip him, muſt worſhip him in Spirit & Truth. And, Rom. 1.9. God is my witneſs, whom I ſerve with my Spirit. &c.) or by the Holy Ghoſt furniſhing us thereto, and aiding us therein, or both: And ſo it is too Superiour a thing, in the Practice of Singing to bear a flant.
Queſt. Can you deſire us to be reconciled to the new way of Singing, when it brings in ſo much diſturbance with it?

Anſ. I muſt needs ask leave here to plead, that the blame is miſlay'd; and the wrong Horſe Sadled. For that which ought to be laid to the weakneſs or ſome men's reaſon, and to ſtrength of paſſion in others, is bro't and charg'd upon Regular Singing. For conſider, if you have an Important Journey to go, and go forth to procure an Horſe, or other requiſites thereto, and a Shower come upon you, or you daſh your Foot againſt a Stone, or by any other Accident you become Wounded, muſt your going forth on the Errand be therefore Cenſured, when it may be the Occaſion is as Rational and Vindicable as can be. We always ſay, it is unreaſonable to meaſure Cauſes by Effects, or Cenſure or Juſtify them by their Conſequents. For then if a Son take to ill Courſes, his Father, as a Father, muſt be blam'd, tho' ſuch Courſes of his Son be never ſo grievous to him, and he never ſo copious in diſſwaſives againſt the ſame.
Queſt. Well if you could ſhew this new way of Singing, were commanded in Scripture, I ſhould not dare ſpeak a word againſt it?

Anſ. If I did not ſuppoſe it there commanded & required, I ſhould not dare ſpeak a word for it. i. e. tho' it be not in terms inſerted, if by juſt Conſequence, I could not fairly deduce it therefrom to my ſatisfaction, I ſhould not appear to Advocate for it. I think it contained in Pſal. 33.2, 3. Praiſe the Lord with Harp, Sing unto him with the Pſaltery, and an Inſtrument of ten Strings. Sing unto him a new Song, play SKILFULLY with a loud Voice. For I can't ſuppoſe, the moral part
〈◊〉
David calls upon the Church of Iſrael to unite their
〈◊〉 , and to engage their Skill to offer the moſt High, the beſt Praiſes they could poſſibly—. When Inſtruments of Muſick, were more Laudable in the Worſhip of God, than now under a more Spiritual Diſpenſation, then the Sweet Singers Direction was, to obſerve the Conſort between Harp and Voice, keep time & meaſure; and manage each their work dexterouſly. Beſides this plain and direct Precept for it, there are very inſtructive and convictive general precepts & hints, in 1 Cor. 14.40.2 Sam. 24.24 Mal. 1.14 & 1 Cor. 12.31. Covet earnestly the beſt Gifts— And how many things do we practice in the Church of God, relating to the Worſhip of God, deduced from general Precepts; only ſuch as Building ſightly and comfortable Meeting-Houſes, putting on our beſt Apparel on the Sabbath, and if at diſtance we take our Horſes to ride &c. that are not in Terms commanded us; Beſides Electing Men of Learning and Gifts, apt to teach, for the Work of the Ministry, that may with fitteſt Expreſſions carry our requeſts to God, in the publick Prayers, and that can chooſe acceptable words for Sermons; whereas illiterate Perſons could with more eaſe and leſs Charge be introduced; which yet you will not hear of or yield to, to avoid the Conſtruction, and imputation; that we count any thing good enough for the Service of God; and that the Lame & Maimed of our Flock, will do well eno', when we know God will have the Male and best of us or nothing.
Queſt. Well, but Regular Singing is not the great Cauſe of Religion, is it?

Anſ. No, but it is one of the well equip'd hand-maidens waiting upon a Religious Exerciſe. If one had gotten a Horſe, Hat, or Garb, that gave offence, or that a Brother were diſturbed at, ſuch might by an act of ſelf-denial conſent to put either any or all of them away, to recover their temper; and no Prejudice, but Credit would be to Religion hereby: but that which is under Conſideration, can't be let drop, without a plain hurt to a main Exerciſe of Religion, altho' it be not itſelf a principal Pillar
〈…〉
ble Singing, and Sing after a ſort, had we learnt neither the new, nor old way of Singing, but to do ſuch a Service moſt miſerably, when we might do it, with more accuracy and Credit; (like them about us that learnt, when we miſs'd our Opportunity, and that may be purpoſely) is contrary to Scripture caution, not to expoſe our good to be evil ſpoken of. Beſides as there are weightier matters of the Law, Judgment, Mercy & Truth, ſo there are under them things weighty, tho' not equally ſo with the other. But I could wiſh, that inſtead of growing into a ferment and controverſy hereabout, we could all ſet our minds to the Apoſtle's rule, Eph. 4.2, 3. With all lowlineſs and meekneſs, with long ſuffering, forbearing one another in love; Endeavouring to keep the unity of the Spirit, in the bond of Peace. And I would have ſuch invectives and flings among Chriſtians kept back, concluding that many will have to retract them in time to come, with the tears of Repentance, and wiſh over and over they had never let them out of their mouths. I could wiſh we were more ſenſible of, and willing to part with, the brokenneſs of our former Singing, and in the mean time let not them that are for Regular Singing, judge the reſt, and vice verſa; for God receives both, if they humbly and faithfully come to Him. And let us go and learn what that meaneth, viz. to Love one another with a pure heart fervently, 1 Pet. 1.22. Finally, To ſuch as profeſs themſelves to be yet in the dark, in reſpect of ſeeing that which is labour'd for to be a gainful Reformation, I muſt needs plead, that to me it promiſes to befriend and ſerve the Intereſt of Religion. And as long as you plead that you are thus blinded about it, I intreat you not to let your Paſſions abroad, nor yet to let your Spirits be ſowred hereat. Tho' I deſire not to hinder your reſenting, and faulting miſconduct with ſome, that have rather too earneſtly ſet themſelves to haſten the matter on. But I would not have any that hope to endure the Tryal at the laſt Day, under the Righteouſneſs of the GREAT REDEEMER, after an innocent and unblameable Walk among Men, I would not have them allow themſelves to fight and ſtrike
ſtand not, to the oppugning and diſcouraging the Intereſt of Religion among us, when, I don't mean Religion in the Eſſentials of it (as when Paul had to retract his error, and ſaid, Act. 26.9. I verily tho't with my ſelf, that I ought to do many things contrary to the Name of Jeſus of Nazereth.) but in the Circumſtantials of it, that have their weight; or our Fathers more than Sixty Years ago and ſince, were out of the way in the Reformation they ſtood for: who could have had Prayers, Sermons, Scriptures, and Sacraments in the Church of England, but could not away with the impoſed and ſuppoſed Adulterating Ceremonies, and were earneſt to have them parted from Ordinances; as Now the flaws & imperfections of our Singing, ſome of our Brethren ſeek to have removed: And our Fathers ſuffered much rather than anger Conſcience in them: And how deſireable was their Practice in their Difficulty for Imitation, in diſcovering ſo much of the true Spirit of Piety, and a Native undiſguis'd Sincerity, in all their conduct; thoughtful, cautious, and humble, in their Applications to God to direct their way, open to Light and Conviction, willing to weigh every thing that deſerved regard, and fearful of being deceived and miſguided in their Conteſts: It were unaccountable to think ſuch were left of God, in matters where the Divine Honour and Credit of Religion was ſo much concerned. Would to God we in our more petty Conteſts could do likewiſe. And in the mean time patiently ſuffer, being moſt afflicted that Religion ſuffers, while ſome too ſtrenuouſly plead for, the more broken and imperfect carrying on its Exerciſes; but are the more to be forborn, becauſe not ſufficiently aware hereof belike, and ſo may be ſaid not to know what they do. And we might wind up with 2 Cor. 13.8. For we can do nothing againſt the Truth, but for the Truth.

But I can't forbear adding, that I think David was a very accurate Singer, and that he us'd many Tunes, and ſome poſſibly that ſome of ours ſay, they can't come into of Conſcience, tho' others ſay it is of Ignorance and Frowardneſs; and that as his mind was much in the exerciſe 〈◊〉
ſo that he had much Communion with God herein, by which he was the better Chriſtian, and that by the help and bleſſing of God he made himſelf ſo much more a Warriour and better Soldier by Singing over and over ſuch Paſſages as that when he took the Field, Pſa. 144.1, 2. I will bleſs the Lord who teacheth my hands to war, and my fingers to fight. And that in the midst of the battle, Pſal. 118 9 They compaſſed me about like Bees, but in the name of the Lord, I will destroy them. Beſide, Pſal. 18.41, 42. They cried but there was none to ſave them, even to the Lord but he anſwered them not. Then did I beat them ſmall as the duſt before the wind, I did caſt them out as dirt in the streets. And that in quitting the field, Pſal. 144.10. It is he that giveth Salvation to Kings, who delivereth David his Servant, from the hurtful Sword. And it ſeems as if that were his Storming Song, when in ſpite of all the Guards his Enemies could ſet, he was reſolved to Scale the Walls of their Fortreſſes, Pſal. 18 29. For by thee have I run thro' a troop, by my God have I leaped over a wall. And Oh! that we were of one mind about the mode of Singing his holy Songs; not only for the ſake of making our ſelves Maſters of Strong Cities and Impregnable Castles if ſent againſt them, and defying Ramparts and Bulwarks, but for the ſake of fighting the good fight of Faith, Scaling Heaven, and taking its Kingdom with Violence, and inheriting with him, and all the Saved there, Eternal Life. Amen.
